node.title: David Schoen, Donald Trump's Impeachment Lawyer, Representing Steve Bannon
node.description: Former White House adviser Steve Bannon was charged with contempt of Congress for defying a subpoena.

node.title: Higher pay, less red tape: U.S. launches effort to recruit talent to fight cyber attacks
node.description: The new system is designed to speed up a notoriously red-taped hiring process.

node.title: Report recommending suspension of slain Chicago cop sparks outrage
node.description: Mayor Lori Lightfoot, said it was the "height of tone-deafness" to recommend that Officer Ella French​, who was fatally shot in August, be suspended.

node.title: Some U.S. states dangle cash and scholarships to get children vaccinated.
node.description: Programs incentivizing children ages 5 to 11 to get inoculated have proliferated since the C.D.C. recommended a coronavirus vaccine for them this month.

node.title: Chinese COVID Worker Reportedly Beats, Kills Dog While Owner in Quarantine
node.description: The alleged incident has caused significant attention and backlash on Chinese social media website Weibo.

node.title: White House Combats Reports of Animosity Between Joe Biden and Kamala Harris
node.description: CNN reported that many in Harris's circle feel that she is being sidelined by Biden aides.

node.title: Donald Trump Sells Off Jewel of His Hotel Empire Amid Conflict of Interest Probe
node.description: A spokesperson for a committee investigating potential constitutional violations over Trump's lease of the hotel said the move wouldn't change anything.

node.title: Pulmonary Embolism Symptoms Explained As Petra Mayer, NPR Books Editor, Dies at 46
node.description: Tributes have poured in for Mayer—known for her love of science fiction, comic books, and cats—with one co-worker saying: "She was the best of us."

node.title: Adelaide Hills man pleads guilty to firearms offences after more than 200 weapons seized
node.description: An Adelaide Hills man has pleaded guilty to more than 80 firearms offences after police seized more than 200 weapons, including an assault rifle, from his rural property.

node.title: People Magazine Heads to New Ownership. Again.
node.description: Still a hit in print, the weekly chronicle of celebs and ordinary people who make news is set to become the property of a company specializing in informational websites.

node.title: Leonid Meteor Shower to Coincide With Partial Lunar Eclipse This Week
node.description: The Leonids are characterized by fast bright meteors, many of which have persistent trains—trails of vaporized material that glow in the sky.

node.title: Coast Guard rescues 11-year-old girl who survived plane crash
node.description: The plane crashed on Michigan's Beaver Island, killing four of the five people on board.

node.title: In Latest Twist in Philippine Politics, President to Run for Senate
node.description: Rodrigo Duterte entered the race days after his daughter announced her bid for vice president. He had previously said he would leave politics at the end of his term.

node.title: Myanmar frees jailed American journalist Danny Fenster three days after 11-year jail sentence
node.description: His release was confirmed by his employer, Sonny Swe, the publisher of Frontier Myanmar, and former US ambassador Bill Richardson, who says Mr Fenster will fly home via Qatar.

node.title: Shell Proposes Shift to Britain, Dropping ‘Royal Dutch’ From Name
node.description: The restructuring is meant to make the company more appealing to investors and make it easier to sell assets, the oil giant said.

node.title: Covid Thanksgiving, Round 2
node.description: How health experts are thinking about the holidays.

node.title: 'I'm the Bad Guy': Congressman Ryan Arrives in Guyana
node.description: As Leo Ryan and various journalists arrive in Guyana, the authorities try to block their progress while Jim Jones gloats.

node.title: Democrats Urge Joe Biden to Impose Vaccine Requirements for Domestic Flights
node.description: Thirty-six congressional Democrats asked the president to take the "necessary and long overdue step" to reduce the chances of a deadly winter surge.

node.title: U.S. journalist Danny Fenster freed from Myanmar prison, on way home
node.description: The American reporter swept up in Myanmar's post-coup unrest was sentenced only days ago to 11 years hard labor, but is now heading for home, U.S. diplomat Bill Richardson says.

node.title: U.S. Journalist Danny Fenster Is Freed From Myanmar Prison
node.description: The release was a rare positive development in the country, which has been torn apart by violence since a February coup.

node.title: Spirit Airlines Flight Makes Emergency Landing After Engine Catches Fire
node.description: The Spirit Airlines Airbus A320 took off at around 7.15 p.m. local time on Sunday, and had to make an emergency landing at 7.50 p.m.

node.title: A near-fatal drunken fall put Shanna on the path to becoming the NSW Local Hero of the Year
node.description: A recovered alcoholic bounced back from a near-death experience to launch a national campaign lobbying to change alcohol culture in the bush.

node.title: Perth family surrounded by flooded roads now facing extreme heat in Simpson Desert
node.description: After being forced to contend with the effects of torrential rain, Ori and Lindsey Zavros and their two young children are now facing time stuck in the Simpson Desert amid a blast of hot weather.

node.title: Fox Glacier fatal helicopter crash inquest: Owner rejects report's criticism
node.description: Six years after one of the country's worst helicopter crashes, a coroner's inquest into the tragedy began today in the Christchurch District Court.

node.title: Dr. Becky Doesn’t Think the Goal of Parenting Is to Make Your Kid Happy
node.description: “Because there are so many ways right now to get around frustration, you have to be mindful to raise kids who learn how to tolerate it.”

node.title: Shopping for Credenzas
node.description: Whether you need a place to put the food and drinks on Thanksgiving or a platform for your TV, a credenza comes in handy.

node.title: A Young Wife Becomes Pregnant — With an Owl
node.description: In Claire Oshetsky’s surrealistic debut, “Chouette,” motherhood presents an otherworldly dichotomy.

node.title: A Landmark Reckoning With America’s Racial Past and Present
node.description: Originally published as a series in The New York Times Magazine and now revised and expanded as a book, “The 1619 Project,” edited by Nikole Hannah-Jones, Caitlin Roper, Ilena Silverman and Jake Silverstein, undertakes an ambitious examination of slavery and its ongoing legacy for Black Americans.

node.title: The Art of Botox
node.description: How facial muscle paralysis insinuated itself into our emotional and creative lives.

node.title: The U.S. surgeon general says blocking vaccine rules creates a ‘setback’ for public health.
node.description: The Biden administration’s attempts to compel vaccination for workers at large companies have been met with considerable resistance.

node.title: Planning for Surgery? You Might Not Need All Those Tests Beforehand.
node.description: Cardiac stress tests, X-rays and other medical tests may not provide useful information before operations, and they could cause harm.

node.title: Why Don’t We Have a Covid Vaccine for Pets?
node.description: Scientists have developed vaccines for cats and dogs, but vaccinating companion animals is not necessary, experts said.

node.title: Pope Francis Sent Me a Letter. It Gives Me Hope as a Gay Catholic.
node.description: Dialogue may be possible between L.G.B.T. Catholics and church leaders, even at the highest levels.

node.title: Why Hans Zimmer Won’t Be Making Music for the Metaverse
node.description: The composer discusses how streaming and A.I. are transforming movie music.

node.title: Monopoly’s Bad Cousin
node.description: Companies use market power to suppress wages as well as to raise prices. The government is finally paying attention.

node.title: Forget Amazon. The Best Gifts Are Closer Than You Think.
node.description: It’s time to revive the tradition of puttering about in our favorite shops, looking for something that would make a loved one’s eyes light up.

node.title: When the Next Thing You Know Is That You Have Covid
node.description: The future of the virus — and violence — in America.

node.title: Can Hydrogen Save Aviation’s Fuel Challenges? It’s Got a Way to Go.
node.description: Small, experimental hydrogen-powered planes are paving the way for net-zero carbon aviation by 2050. But the route is rocky.

node.title: Feeding the Hungry, and Helping Struggling Restaurants Too
node.description: A New Jersey program that helps nonprofit organizations partner with restaurants is helping people and small businesses stay afloat during the pandemic.

node.title: How America’s Pandemic Economic Response Fought the Last War
node.description: A focus on the challenges of the Great Recession has fueled some of the challenges of this crisis.

node.title: Jurors Await Closing Arguments in Kyle Rittenhouse Trial
node.description: The prosecution and defense are each allotted two and a half hours on Monday to convince jurors whether Mr. Rittenhouse was legally justified in shooting three men in Kenosha, Wis.

node.title: In Death Penalty Cases, an Impatient Supreme Court
node.description: Recent rulings, including one turning down a death row inmate’s request supported by the prosecution, offer telling glimpses of the state of capital punishment.

node.title: Underdog No More, a Deaf Football Team Takes California by Storm
node.description: The California School for the Deaf, Riverside, is steamrolling its opponents, electrifying a campus that has seen more than a few athletic defeats.

node.title: Four Lives Lost in Another American Pandemic: Homicides
node.description: In many cities, towns and rural areas, homicides are up in 2021, even after a sharp rise last year. The reasons are elusive. The impact is immeasurable. Here are four stories from one month that offer a glimpse of the toll.

node.title: Biden and Xi to Meet Amid Economic and Military Tensions
node.description: U.S. officials said the virtual summit on Monday was intended to reassure both sides that misunderstandings would not lead to unintended clashes.

node.title: Inside the Struggle to Save Bulgaria’s Last Narrow-Gauge Railroad
node.description: The Rhodope Narrow-Gauge Railway serves remote communities in southwestern Bulgaria. Can longtime riders — and young enthusiasts — keep it running?

node.title: A New Source of Fuel in an Aging Japan: Adult Incontinence
node.description: Waste from adult diapers is growing by tens of thousands of tons a year in Japan. One town may have a solution: recycle it into fuel pellets.

node.title: U.S. 'Has No Strategy' for Cyber War, Garry Kasparov Warns
node.description: The former world chess champion, who is now Avast's security ambassador, outlined how America should deal with cyber threats.

node.title: 'Terrorists' at the Border? To Please Donald Trump, Homeland Security Tweaked Reports
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: What Austria's Lockdown for Those Unvaccinated Against COVID Really Means
node.description: Under the temporary new rules, Austrians not fully vaccinated against COVID are only permitted to leave their homes for certain reasons.
